Metadata: Efficient catalysis of polysiloxane synthesis by silcatein "alpha" requires specific hydroxy and imidazole functionalities

Silicatein "alpha" is the principal subunit comprising about 70% of the mass of the silica protein filaments of a marine sponge. The authors of this report demonstrate that the functional hydroxy and imidazole side chains of serine- 26 and histidine-165, which were identified from the structure of silicatein "alpha" as its putative active site, are required for the protein's efficient and specific catalysis of alkoxysilane polycondensatio​n at neutral pH. These observations may prove useful in the design of synthetic catalysts for environmentally benign synthesis of silica and organically modified polysilsesquiox​anes.
